greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle T(n,k) read by rows, for 1 <= k <= n: minimal number of knights needed to cover a k X n board.
comment: How many knights are needed to occupy or attack every square of a k X n board?
I do not know how many of these numbers have been proved to be optimal. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Nov 08 2004
link: Frank Rubin, Knight coverings for large chessboards, 2000.
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Knights Problem.
example: Triangle (with rows n >= 1 and columns k >= 1) begins as follows:
xref: See A006075 for the n X n case (the main diagonal). A006076 gives number of ways to cover an n X n board using the minimal number of knights.
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_
ext: Morgenstern's table extends a long way beyond what is shown here.
